name: Household Income 2015
title: Household Income 2015

api_list.name: /records
api_list.description: The 'records' endpoint of the 'HouseholdIncome2015' API is the primary destination to obtain relevant information about income records. When you make a request to this endpoint, it will return an array of objects that correspond to the rows in the database associated with your specific query parameters. By accessing the 'records' endpoint, users gain access to valuable data concerning household income in 2015. This information could be useful for a wide range of individuals, including researchers, policymakers, and even individuals who are interested in understanding income trends. By utilizing the query parameters, users can narrow down the results to specific criteria of interest, such as geographical location or other relevant factors.The 'records' endpoint offers a user-friendly approach to exploring and visualizing income data from 2015. It provides an opportunity to gain insights into income distribution and disparities, enabling users to develop a better understanding of the economic landscape during that time period. Whether seeking data for academic purposes or personal interest, the 'records' endpoint empowers users to explore and analyze the income records that matter to them.

api_list.name: /marginOfErrorAggregateHouseholdIncome
api_list.description: The endpoint 'marginOfErrorAggregateHouseholdIncome' from the API 'HouseholdIncome2015' provides a list of potential values for the field 'marginOfErrorAggregateHouseholdIncome'. This field represents the margin of error associated with the aggregated household income data. By accessing this endpoint, you will receive an array of strings that contains different possible values for the margin of error. These values help to quantify the statistical uncertainty in the gathered household income data. The margin of error is typically represented as a range around the reported aggregate household income.This endpoint is useful for understanding the reliability and precision of the provided household income data. It allows users to assess the confidence level associated with the reported aggregated income figures. By considering the range of potential margin of error values, users can make more informed decisions or interpretations when working with the dataset.

api_list.name: /dataListIndex
api_list.description: The 'dataListIndex' endpoint in the 'HouseholdIncome2015' API provides a list of options or choices for a specific field called 'dataListIndex'. This field represents different categories or indices related to household income data for the year 2015. By using this endpoint, users can retrieve an array of strings which represents all the available options for this field.This endpoint is useful for users who need to access and analyze data related to household income and want to explore different categories or indices within that data. The array of strings returned by this endpoint could include labels such as 'Low Income', 'Middle Income', 'High Income', or more specific descriptions like 'Income range $30,000 - $40,000', 'Income range $40,000 - $50,000', etc.By understanding and utilizing the values provided by this endpoint, users can filter, sort, or categorize the household income data according to their specific needs, allowing them to gain insights and make informed decisions based on the different categories or indices available within the data.

api_list.name: /neighborhood
api_list.description: The 'neighborhood' endpoint from the 'HouseholdIncome2015' API provides a range of options for the field 'neighborhood'. This endpoint allows you to access an array of strings that represent different neighborhoods. These neighborhoods could be within a city, town, or any defined area. By using this endpoint, you can retrieve all the possible values for the 'neighborhood' field available in the dataset.For example, if you were looking for neighborhoods in a specific city, you could use this endpoint to obtain a comprehensive list of different areas within that city. This information can be valuable for various purposes such as understanding income distribution across neighborhoods, conducting demographic analyses, or creating location-based applications.By accessing the 'neighborhood' endpoint, you gain access to a collection of neighborhood names, enabling you to explore and utilize this data effectively.

api_list.name: /id
api_list.description: The 'id' endpoint in the 'HouseholdIncome2015' API provides a list of unique identifiers representing various categories related to household income. These identifiers serve as reference points for different segments or groups within the data. For instance, an 'id' might represent a specific income range, geographical region, or demographic category. These values help categorize and organize the income data for further analysis or comparison purposes. By exploring the 'id' endpoint, users can access an array of strings, each representing a different possible 'id'. These strings can be utilized to filter and retrieve specific subsets of income data based on the desired criteria.Overall, the 'id' endpoint plays a crucial role in navigating and understanding the available data within the 'HouseholdIncome2015' API, enabling users to gain insights into the income distribution and related factors.

api_list.name: /estimateAggregateHouseholdIncome
api_list.description: The endpoint 'estimateAggregateHouseholdIncome' from the API 'HouseholdIncome2015' provides a user-friendly way to retrieve a list of possible values for the 'estimateAggregateHouseholdIncome' field. This field represents the estimated aggregate household income for a given dataset in the year 2015. The endpoint returns an array of strings, where each string represents a possible value for the estimated aggregate household income. These values can range from very low incomes to high incomes and are categorized based on different income brackets. By accessing this endpoint, users can obtain a comprehensive list of income ranges that are relevant for analyzing and understanding the household income distribution within a specific dataset.
